{"messages":[{"id":570915563,"sender":"Kevin Buzzard","content":"At least in this variant not one but both sides are invariant under z maps to z+1 :-)","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:24.115Z","reactions":[]},{"id":570989329,"sender":"Thomas Waring","content":"Jesse Alama said:

My longer-term goal is to prove the equivalence of URM-computability with CSLib's existing SKI calculus, establishing another bridge between computation models in the library.

Very glad to see that the SKI developments are proving useful! I had grand plans of proving Partrec -> SKI (most of the pieces ought to be in SKI/Recursion) but never got around to fixing what it means for a term to compute a partial function in a way I was 100% happy with. If there are any developments on the SKI side that would be helpful please let me know :-))","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:24.115Z","reactions":[]},{"id":570992173,"sender":"Sati","content":"Hello, all. I am from IIT Gandhinagar. We're interested in hosting a workshop on LEAN4 specifically oriented towards using and contributing to CSLib. The motivation for this is that (as far as I know) a lot of the current material on LEAN is either on the functional programming aspects within LEAN itself, oriented towards primarily mathematicians, or related to PL Theory specifically.
I don't think the 3 goals stated in CSLib are captured by these appropriately, and it would be nice to work on something that does. This would require some careful thought about structure and pacing (For example, one could consider a tutorial on Aeneas in the workshop with respect to goal 3). 
I would appreciate comments and critiques on this idea. Invitations to help are welcome too! Thanks a lot!
(PS: I'm expecting that the audience will be students from both the undergraduate and postgraduate levels.)","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:24.115Z","reactions":[]},{"id":571118877,"sender":"Chris Henson","content":"I think this is getting a bit sidetracked. I agree with Ching-Tsun that the cleaner generalization is a class over arbitrary relations, and if we really have to we can consider the structure part afterwards. I liked the direction when you proposed:

    
        
        
        
    class RightCongruence (α β : Type*) (f : β → α → α) extends
  eq : Setoid α, right_cov : CovariantClass β α f eq

it just needs to be shown that it works with left/right variants.","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:24.115Z","reactions":[]},{"id":571132065,"sender":"Ruben Van de Velde","content":"Doesn't seem to change it on my side","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:24.115Z","reactions":[]},{"id":571136216,"sender":"Chris Henson","content":"I would need to see concretely what you're proposing and that it doesn't break anything in STLC or System F. My guess is it will be delicate interacting with the locally nameless binding, but I am happy to consider a PR proving me wrong!
We are planning to additionally support something like this style of substitution, closely following Autosubst, but this is a longer term project because of the metaprogramming involved.","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:24.115Z","reactions":[]},{"id":571136542,"sender":"David Wegmann","content":"At the moment I'll only try to produce a single file strongnorm.lean :)
Did you consider nominal techniques for variable management?","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:24.115Z","reactions":[]},{"id":571142937,"sender":"cmlsharp","content":"As a side note if this is indeed a useful pattern in general, I think it would be neat if this was facilitated by somehow by a version of csimp that takes these assumptions as arguments. Right now you have to do something akin to this little dance where you define e.g.

    
        
        
        
    def f_impl (h_assumption : ..) ..  := ..
unsafe def f_unsafe .. := f_impl lcProof  ..
@[implemented_by f_unsafe]
def f .. := ..

(and then some theorem where you say that given h_assumption, f is equivalent to f_impl. f_impl needn’t always take the assumption as an argument but sometimes it needs to)
But you could imagine syntax that let you write just f_impl and f and then let you write

    
        
        
        
    @[csimp_assuming(h_assumption)]
theorem (h_assumption : ..) ..

Perhaps I could try something like this as a PR to Batteries","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:24.115Z","reactions":[]},{"id":571144081,"sender":"Kim Morrison","content":"Beyond that, I think we should consider deprecating SatisfiesM itself / moving it elsewhere, and just direct people to using mvcgen. 
As far as I am aware there are no downstream projects that use SatisfiesM, except for https://github.com/FormalSAT/trestle which only uses it in a file called Trash.lean!
Within Batteries, there are many theorems with SatisfiesM in their conclusion (so, I think, deprecatable along with the framework), and then three that feel somewhat more useful (but, per above, have never been used):

    
        
        
        
    theorem

{"messages":[{"id":452452974,"sender":"Leo Diedering","content":"Floris van Doorn schrieb:

Leo Diedering two small comments (that are not urgent): could you make sure that every result in chapter 10 and 11 where the statement has a \leanok has a corresponding non-empty \lean{...} command? And could you make sure that classical-Carleson is the unique minimal element in the dependency graph? (two-sided-metric-space-Carleson likely needs a bunch more entries in its uses{} command).

Yes, there are definitely entries missing. I will try to add them soon.","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:33.185Z","reactions":[]},{"id":473689149,"sender":"Anand Rao Tadipatri","content":"I may have a slightly different way to prove @Hernán Ibarra Mejia's metatheorem (adapting the proof from the blueprint) that may generalize to other invariants of expressions.
Let w≃w′w \simeq w'w≃w′ be a law such that every variable appears the same number of times in both www and w′w'w′, and let w′′≃w′′′w'' \simeq w'''w′′≃w′′′ be a law implied by it. Further, assume that these expressions contain at most nnn variables x1,x2,…,xnx_1, x_2, \ldots, x_nx1​,x2​,…,xn​. The condition on the law w≃w′w \simeq w'w≃w′ is equivalent to the statement that evaluating both expressions www and w′w'w′ in the magma (Zn,+)(\mathbb{Z}^n, +)(Zn,+) under the substitution xi↦bix_i \mapsto b_ixi​↦bi​, where bib_ibi​ is the iii th basis vector of the form (0,0,…,1,…,0)(0, 0, \ldots, 1, \ldots, 0)(0,0,…,1,…,0), yields equal elements of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn.
It turns out that (Zn,+)(\mathbb{Z}^n, +)(Zn,+) is in fact a model of the law w≃w′w \simeq w'w≃w′. Consider nnn arbitrary elements v1,v2,…,vnv_1, v_2, \ldots, v_nv1​,v2​,…,vn​ of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn. Performing the substitution xi↦vix_i \mapsto v_ixi​↦vi​ in an expression is equivalent to first performing the substitution xi↦bix_i \mapsto b_ixi​↦bi​ and then applying the unique endomorphism of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn sending each bib_ibi​ to viv_ivi​. By assumption, both expressions www and w′w'w′ evaluate to the same element of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn after the substitution xi↦bix_i \mapsto b_ixi​↦bi​, and therefore, they evaluate to the same element of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn after the substitution xi↦vix_i \mapsto v_ixi​↦vi​. This holds for any set of elements v1,v2,…,vnv_1, v_2, \ldots, v_nv1​,v2​,…,vn​ of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn, and hence (Zn,+)(\mathbb{Z}^n, +)(Zn,+) is a model for the law w≃w′w \simeq w'w≃w′.
This means that (Zn,+)(\mathbb{Z}^n, +)(Zn,+) is also a model for the law w′′≃w′′′w'' \simeq w'''w′′≃w′′′, since this is assumed to be implied by w≃w′w \simeq w'w≃w′. In particular, this means that performing the substitution xi↦bix_i \mapsto b_ixi​↦bi​ evaluates both w′′w''w′′ and w′′′w'''w′′′ to the same element of Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn. This is equivalent to saying that w′′w''w′′ and w′′′w'''w′′′ have the same multisets of variables appearing in them, and the result follows.","timestamp":"2026-02-06T17:47:33.185Z","reactions":[]},{"id":475126048,"sender":"Anand Rao Tadipatri","content":"@Andrés Goens This is the general idea behind @Hernán Ibarra Mejia's metatheorem (theorem 4.8 in the blueprint) about counting variables on both sides of the equation, which has been expanded upon in Chapter 8 of the blueprint. {"result":"--- Unknown ---
Discussion thread for #announce > Side-by-side blueprint - Experience prototype

--- Unknown ---
I see you are putting this on a website. Is it possible to instead have this as a vscode extension or in the lean infoview? The one most annoying thing for me is how long it takes to build the blueprint, only to realise you've missed a dependency...

--- Unknown ---
You can serve it locally, where it builds much faster. (That's what I typically do with PNT+ and RealAnalysisGame projects.)

--- Unknown ---
Yes, but I couldn't easily do this until recently due to gitpod wiping out any local config when restarting a workspace. Now that I use the uni's big computer, it shouldn't be so much of an issue anymore

--- Unknown ---
Yaël Dillies said:

I see you are putting this on a website. Is it possible to instead have this as a vscode extension or in the lean infoview? The one most annoying thing for me is how long it takes to build the blueprint, only to realise you've missed a dependency...

Displaying things in the info view seems like a great idea that I had not considered. It's a bit tight on space though, what were you imagining? showing the rendered Latex of he declaration you're in?
I set up some basic caching, although it's still a bit brittle (and dep. graph change triggers a complete rebuild).  I will work on it a bit more this evening. Here are the preliminary results. I expect that they won't get much better than this, but there is still a bit of work to do on making sure it doesn't break. (this is from the first and only successful run)
Screenshot 2026-02-05 at 6.46.26 PM.png
Also I thought about doing a VSCode extension, but could not decide on how I wanted to do it. There are a lot of design decisions to be made in terms of where the lean and latex go, and where the rendered content gets displayed. I decided to opt out and just display it via html because that seemed to be pretty popular with the original leanblueprint and I figured people would not want to change workflows that much. In principle there is nothing stoping us from doing both.

--- Unknown ---
My idea having it in vscode is simply to avoid switching back and forth many times between vscode and my browser. The infoview ultimately is just displayed html, so you could simply strip down your page slightly (so that it fits on a narrow window, and display it in vscode","type":"string"}

{"result":"[1] Eric Vergo:
Discussion thread for #announce > Side-by-side blueprint - Experience prototype

---

[2] Yaël Dillies:
I see you are putting this on a website. Is it possible to instead have this as a vscode extension or in the lean infoview? The one most annoying thing for me is how long it takes to build the blueprint, only to realise you've missed a dependency...

---

[3] Alex Kontorovich:
You can serve it locally, where it builds much faster. (That's what I typically do with PNT+ and RealAnalysisGame projects.)

---

[4] Yaël Dillies:
Yes, but I couldn't easily do this until recently due to gitpod wiping out any local config when restarting a workspace. Now that I use the uni's big computer, it shouldn't be so much of an issue anymore

---

[5] Eric Vergo:
Yaël Dillies said:

I see you are putting this on a website. Is it possible to instead have this as a vscode extension or in the lean infoview? The one most annoying thing for me is how long it takes to build the blueprint, only to realise you've missed a dependency...

Displaying things in the info view seems like a great idea that I had not considered. It's a bit tight on space though, what were you imagining? showing the rendered Latex of he declaration you're in?

I set up some basic caching, although it's still a bit brittle (and dep. graph change triggers a complete rebuild). I will work on it a bit more this evening. Here are the preliminary results. I expect that they won't get much better than this, but there is still a bit of work to do on making sure it doesn't break. (this is from the first and only successful run)

Screenshot 2026-02-05 at 6.46.26 PM.png

Also I thought about doing a VSCode extension, but could not decide on how I wanted to do it. There are a lot of design decisions to be made in terms of where the lean and latex go, and where the rendered content gets displayed. I decided to opt out and just display it via html because that seemed to be pretty popular with the original leanblueprint and I figured people would not want to change workflows that much. In principle there is nothing stoping us from doing both.

---

[6] Yaël Dillies:
My idea having it in vscode is simply to avoid switching back and forth many times between vscode and my browser. The infoview ultimately is just displayed html, so you could simply strip down your page slightly (so that it fits on a narrow window, and display it in vscode

{"success":true,"issue":{"number":224,"title":"Epic: SBS Rewrite - From Prototype to First-Class Experience","state":"OPEN","labels":["ai-authored","feature:new","scope:architectural"],"url":"https://github.com/e-vergo/SLS-Strange-Loop-Station/issues/224","body":"## Overview

This epic tracks the transformation of SBS from a prototype to a first-class experience, addressing feedback from the Lean community:

- **Yaël Dillies**: Build times too long; wants VSCode/infoview integration
- **Alex Kontorovich**: TeX and Lean should live in same file (PNT+ delimiter approach)

**Core insight:** Feedback loop latency is the real pain point. The solution is aggressive caching + unified TeX/Lean model + IDE-ready backend.

## Plan Document

Full implementation plan: [`dev/markdowns/living/REWRITE_PLAN.md`](https://github.com/e-vergo/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/blob/main/dev/markdowns/living/REWRITE_PLAN.md)

## Phases

### Phase 1: Caching Infrastructure (Highest Impact)
**Goal:** Reduce typical rebuild from ~5-7s to ~1-2s

- [ ] 1.1 Manifest hash cache for graph generation
- [ ] 1.2 Per-declaration content-addressed cache
- [ ] 1.3 SubVerso highlighting optimization
- [ ] 1.4 Asset pipeline optimization

### Phase 2: Unified TeX/Lean Model
**Goal:** Support both Lean-first and Paper-first workflows with validation

- [ ] 2.1 Delimiter-based statement embedding (PNT+ style `/-%%...%%-/`)
- [ ] 2.2 Statement-signature validation
- [ ] 2.3 Paper.tex bidirectional linking
- [ ] 2.4 Unified configuration

### Phase 3: IDE-Ready Backend
**Goal:** Infrastructure that enables VSCode extension without building it

- [ ] 3.1 Real-time artifact export
- [ ] 3.2 MCP extension for IDE queries
- [ ] 3.3 JSON schema stabilization
- [ ] 3.4 Editor decoration data

### Phase 4: VSCode Extension (Future)
Out of scope for this epic, but enabled by Phases 1-3.

## Success Criteria

### Quantitative
- Incremental rebuild < 1s (no Lean changes)
- Full rebuild < 4s (SBS-Test scale)
- Cache hit rate > 80% for typical development

### Qualitative
- Alex can use PNT+ delimiter workflow in SBS
- Yaël's dependency errors caught before full build
- New users can start with paper.tex and migrate to Lean-first
- VSCode extension has all data it needs

## Sub-Issues

### Wave 1: Quick Wins
- [ ] #225 - Manifest hash cache for graph generation (1.1)
- [ ] #226 - Asset pipeline optimization (1.4)
- [ ] #227 - Unified runway.json configuration (2.4)

### Wave 2: Core Caching
- [ ] #228 - Per-declaration content-addressed cache (1.2)
- [ ] #229 - JSON schema stabilization (3.3)

### Wave 3-5: (Issues to be created)
- Wave 3: Unified Model (2.1, 2.3)
- Wave 4: Validation (2.2, 3.1, 3.4)
- Wave 5: IDE Backend (1.3, 3.2)

## Context

- [Zulip announcement thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113486-announce/topic/Side-by-side.20blueprint.20-.20Experience.20prototype)
- [Zulip discussion thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/274007-ecosystem.20infrastructure/topic/Discussion.20thread.20-.20Side.20by.20Side.20blueprint)

---
🤖 Created with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)","created_at":"2026-02-05T19:36:26Z"},"error":null}

tool_calls.result_content:
## Overview

This epic tracks the transformation of SBS from a prototype to a first-class experience, addressing feedback from the Lean community:

- **Yaël Dillies**: Build times too long; wants VSCode/infoview integration
- **Alex Kontorovich**: TeX and Lean should live in same file (PNT+ delimiter approach)

**Core insight:** Feedback loop latency is the real pain point. The solution is aggressive caching + unified TeX/Lean model + IDE-ready backend.

## Plan Document

Full implementation plan: [`dev/markdowns/living/REWRITE_PLAN.md`](https://github.com/e-vergo/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/blob/main/dev/markdowns/living/REWRITE_PLAN.md)

## Phases

### Phase 1: Caching Infrastructure (Highest Impact)
**Goal:** Reduce typical rebuild from ~5-7s to ~1-2s

- [ ] 1.1 Manifest hash cache for graph generation
- [ ] 1.2 Per-declaration content-addressed cache
- [ ] 1.3 SubVerso highlighting optimization
- [ ] 1.4 Asset pipeline optimization

### Phase 2: Unified TeX/Lean Model
**Goal:** Support both Lean-first and Paper-first workflows with validation

- [ ] 2.1 Delimiter-based statement embedding (PNT+ style `/-%%...%%-/`)
- [ ] 2.2 Statement-signature validation
- [ ] 2.3 Paper.tex bidirectional linking
- [ ] 2.4 Unified configuration

### Phase 3: IDE-Ready Backend
**Goal:** Infrastructure that enables VSCode extension without building it

- [ ] 3.1 Real-time artifact export
- [ ] 3.2 MCP extension for IDE queries
- [ ] 3.3 JSON schema stabilization
- [ ] 3.4 Editor decoration data

### Phase 4: VSCode Extension (Future)
Out of scope for this epic, but enabled by Phases 1-3.

## Success Criteria

### Quantitative
- Incremental rebuild < 1s (no Lean changes)
- Full rebuild < 4s (SBS-Test scale)
- Cache hit rate > 80% for typical development

### Qualitative
- Alex can use PNT+ delimiter workflow in SBS
- Yaël's dependency errors caught before full build
- New users can start with paper.tex and migrate to Lean-first
- VSCode extension has all data it needs

## Sub-Issues

### Wave 1: Quick Wins
- [ ] #225 - Manifest hash cache for graph generation (1.1)
- [ ] #226 - Asset pipeline optimization (1.4)
- [ ] #227 - Unified runway.json configuration (2.4)

### Wave 2: Core Caching
- [ ] #228 - Per-declaration content-addressed cache (1.2)
- [ ] #229 - JSON schema stabilization (3.3)

### Wave 3-5: (Issues to be created)
- Wave 3: Unified Model (2.1, 2.3)
- Wave 4: Validation (2.2, 3.1, 3.4)
- Wave 5: IDE Backend (1.3, 3.2)

## Context

- [Zulip announcement thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113486-announce/topic/Side-by-side.20blueprint.20-.20Experience.20prototype)
- [Zulip discussion thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/274007-ecosystem.20infrastructure/topic/Discussion.20thread.20-.20Side.20by.20Side.20blueprint)

---

input_full.command:
gh issue edit 224 --body "$(cat <<'ENDOFBODY'
## Overview

This epic tracks the transformation of SBS from a prototype to a first-class experience, addressing feedback from the Lean community:

- **Yaël Dillies**: Build times too long; wants to avoid context-switching between VSCode and browser. Suggested displaying stripped-down SBS HTML directly in the VSCode infoview panel.
- **Alex Kontorovich**: TeX and Lean should live in same file (PNT+ delimiter approach, confirmed offline)

**Core insight:** Feedback loop latency is the real pain point. The solution is aggressive caching + unified TeX/Lean model + IDE-ready backend.

## Caching Baselines

Preliminary caching results from the prototype (first successful run):

| Project | Cold Build | Cached | Rebuild % |
|---------|-----------|--------|-----------|
| GCR (57 nodes) | 42.9s | 13.2s | 69% |
| PNT (527 nodes) | 23.5 min | 17.9s | 98.7% |

These numbers validate Phase 1's priority and ground the success criteria below.

## Plan Document

Full implementation plan: [`dev/markdowns/living/REWRITE_PLAN.md`](https://github.com/e-vergo/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/blob/main/dev/markdowns/living/REWRITE_PLAN.md)

## Phases

### Phase 1: Caching Infrastructure (Highest Impact)
**Goal:** Reduce typical rebuild from ~5-7s to ~1-2s

- [ ] 1.1 Manifest hash cache for graph generation
- [ ] 1.2 Per-declaration content-addressed cache
- [ ] 1.3 SubVerso highlighting optimization
- [ ] 1.4 Asset pipeline optimization

### Phase 2: Unified TeX/Lean Model
**Goal:** Support both Lean-first and Paper-first workflows with validation

- [ ] 2.1 Delimiter-based statement embedding (PNT+ style `/-%%...%%-/`)
- [ ] 2.2 Statement-signature validation
- [ ] 2.3 Paper.tex bidirectional linking
- [ ] 2.4 Unified configuration

### Phase 3: IDE-Ready Backend
**Goal:** Infrastructure that enables VSCode extension without building it

- [ ] 3.1 Real-time artifact export
- [ ] 3.2 MCP extension for IDE queries
- [ ] 3.3 JSON schema stabilization
- [ ] 3.4 Editor decoration data

### Phase 4: VSCode Extension (Future)
Out of scope for this epic, but enabled by Phases 1-3.

## Success Criteria

### Quantitative
- Incremental rebuild < 1s (no Lean changes)
- Full rebuild < 4s (SBS-Test scale)
- Cache hit rate > 80% for typical development

### Qualitative
- Alex can use PNT+ delimiter workflow in SBS
- Yaël's dependency errors caught before full build
- New users can start with paper.tex and migrate to Lean-first
- VSCode extension has all data it needs

## Sub-Issues

### Wave 1: Quick Wins
- [ ] #225 - Manifest hash cache for graph generation (1.1)
- [ ] #226 - Asset pipeline optimization (1.4)
- [ ] #227 - Unified runway.json configuration (2.4)

### Wave 2: Core Caching
- [ ] #228 - Per-declaration content-addressed cache (1.2)
- [ ] #229 - JSON schema stabilization (3.3)

### Wave 3-5: (Issues to be created)
- Wave 3: Unified Model (2.1, 2.3)
- Wave 4: Validation (2.2, 3.1, 3.4)
- Wave 5: IDE Backend (1.3, 3.2)

## Context

- [Zulip announcement thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113486-announce/topic/Side-by-side.20blueprint.20-.20Experience.20prototype)
- [Zulip discussion thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/536994-ecosystem-infrastructure/topic/Discussion.20thread.20-.20Side.20by.20Side.20blueprint)

---
🤖 Created with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)
ENDOFBODY
